trans-unit.source: Handling and throwing exceptions in .NET
trans-unit.target: Handling and throwing exceptions in .NET

trans-unit.source: Applications must be able to handle errors that occur during execution in a consistent manner.
trans-unit.target: Applications must be able to handle errors that occur during execution in a consistent manner.

trans-unit.source: .NET provides a model for notifying applications of errors in a uniform way: .NET operations indicate failure by throwing exceptions.
trans-unit.target: .NET provides a model for notifying applications of errors in a uniform way: .NET operations indicate failure by throwing exceptions.

trans-unit.source: Exceptions
trans-unit.target: Exceptions

trans-unit.source: An exception is any error condition or unexpected behavior that is encountered by an executing program.
trans-unit.target: An exception is any error condition or unexpected behavior that is encountered by an executing program.

trans-unit.source: Exceptions can be thrown because of a fault in your code or in code that you call (such as a shared library), unavailable operating system resources, unexpected conditions that the runtime encounters (such as code that cannot be verified), and so on.
trans-unit.target: Exceptions can be thrown because of a fault in your code or in code that you call (such as a shared library), unavailable operating system resources, unexpected conditions that the runtime encounters (such as code that cannot be verified), and so on.

trans-unit.source: Your application can recover from some of these conditions, but not from others.
trans-unit.target: Your application can recover from some of these conditions, but not from others.

trans-unit.source: Although you can recover from most application exceptions, you cannot recover from most runtime exceptions.
trans-unit.target: Although you can recover from most application exceptions, you cannot recover from most runtime exceptions.

trans-unit.source: In .NET, an exception is an object that inherits from the [System.Exception](https://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/api/System.Exception) class.
trans-unit.target: In .NET, an exception is an object that inherits from the [System.Exception](https://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/api/System.Exception) class.

trans-unit.source: An exception is thrown from an area of code where a problem has occurred.
trans-unit.target: An exception is thrown from an area of code where a problem has occurred.

trans-unit.source: The exception is passed up the stack until the application handles it or the program terminates.
trans-unit.target: The exception is passed up the stack until the application handles it or the program terminates.

trans-unit.source: Exceptions vs. traditional error-handling methods
trans-unit.target: Exceptions vs. traditional error-handling methods

trans-unit.source: Traditionally, a language's error-handling model relied on either the language's unique way of detecting errors and locating handlers for them, or on the error-handling mechanism provided by the operating system.
trans-unit.target: Traditionally, a language's error-handling model relied on either the language's unique way of detecting errors and locating handlers for them, or on the error-handling mechanism provided by the operating system.

trans-unit.source: The way .NET implements exception handling provides the following advantages:
trans-unit.target: The way .NET implements exception handling provides the following advantages:

trans-unit.source: Exception throwing and handling works the same for .NET programming languages.
trans-unit.target: Exception throwing and handling works the same for .NET programming languages.

trans-unit.source: Does not require any particular language syntax for handling exceptions, but allows each language to define its own syntax.
trans-unit.target: Does not require any particular language syntax for handling exceptions, but allows each language to define its own syntax.

trans-unit.source: Exceptions can be thrown across process and even machine boundaries.
trans-unit.target: Exceptions can be thrown across process and even machine boundaries.

trans-unit.source: Exception-handling code can be added to an application to increase program reliability.
trans-unit.target: Exception-handling code can be added to an application to increase program reliability.

trans-unit.source: Exceptions offer advantages over other methods of error notification, such as return codes.
trans-unit.target: Exceptions offer advantages over other methods of error notification, such as return codes.

trans-unit.source: Failures do not go unnoticed because if an exception is thrown and you don't handle it, the runtime terminates your application.
trans-unit.target: Failures do not go unnoticed because if an exception is thrown and you don't handle it, the runtime terminates your application.

trans-unit.source: Invalid values do not continue to propagate through the system as a result of code that fails to check for a failure return code.
trans-unit.target: Invalid values do not continue to propagate through the system as a result of code that fails to check for a failure return code.

trans-unit.target: Handle common conditions without throwing exceptions

trans-unit.source: For conditions that are likely to occur but might trigger an exception, consider handling them in a way that will avoid the exception.
trans-unit.target: For conditions that are likely to occur but might trigger an exception, consider handling them in a way that will avoid the exception.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you try to close a connection that is already closed, you'll get an `InvalidOperationException`.

trans-unit.source: You can avoid that by using an **if** statement to check the connection state before trying to close it.

trans-unit.source: For example, on .NET runtimes that implement App Domains, exceptions may occur across App domains.
trans-unit.target: For example, on .NET runtimes that implement App Domains, exceptions may occur across App domains.

trans-unit.source: Suppose App Domain A creates App Domain B, which executes code that throws an exception.
trans-unit.target: Suppose App Domain A creates App Domain B, which executes code that throws an exception.

trans-unit.source: For App Domain A to properly catch and handle the exception, it must be able to find the assembly that contains the exception thrown by App Domain B. If App Domain B throws an exception that is contained in an assembly under its application base, but not under App Domain A's application base, App Domain A will not be able to find the exception, and the common language runtime will throw a [FileNotFoundException](https://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/api/System.IO.FileNotFoundException) exception.
trans-unit.target: For App Domain A to properly catch and handle the exception, it must be able to find the assembly that contains the exception thrown by App Domain B.
